description: Hangs the entire GUI upon launch. Just started happening today, absolute garbage that a text editor can hang up the whole system.
it does everything from code editing to normal textfile it just needs code keywrds suggestion
Simple and functional!
I'd appreciate adding text scaling with Ctrl+mouse wheel.

- No easy way to comment or uncomment multiple lines of text
- Can't click-and-drag on the line numbers to select multiple lines of text
- No block selection mode
- Doesn't use standard ctrl+pgup/pgdn keyboard shortcuts for tab navigation
- No "open containing folder" feature

Not bad for "casual" text editing, but to get real work done, you'll want to install something more powerful like Sublime Text or Kate.
A good starting editor that can edit plain text or configuration files but also write code. It comes with a lot of useful extensions

GEdit integrates really well into the GNOME desktop, and it is perfect for small plain-text editing tasks.
Unfortunately it falls short as a text-editor for programming languages, where it often fails to indent code correctly, sometimes tries to spellcheck code, which makes no sense etc.
So, for small plaintext-editing tasks, it's a great tool, for programming not so much, because many features which would make GEdit a great programmers text-editor are sacrificed for the simplicity of the "I just want to write a plaintext file" usecase - which IMHO happens rarely to the non-technical user.
Without plugins, GEdit isn't as great as it could be (but fortunately, there are plugins!).

I use it as my main programming text editor. It's simple, but also surprisingly powerful. Syntax highlighting, spellchecking, regex search and replace? Yes please. And unlike many other GNOME apps, it's extremely rare that I find bugs in gedit. This thing is one of the most stable apps I've ever used.
summary: One of the best GNOME apps

description: When programming I use an IDE. When writing I use a document editor. Gedit is both and neither. It is the handy little Swiss army knife with which you can solve simple problems with ease. If I quickly need to open a config file and edit a string I use gedit. If I quickly need to write a note to myself, I use gedit. Gedit starts fast, takes no space and is reliable.
summary: A tool for all the quick and small tasks

description: It's a great application: clean and intuitive interface and the right balance between ease of use and features. A good number of installable plugins makes it also an adeguate editor for more complex tasks.
Excellent text editor
The ease-of-use makes this GUI based text editor a top choice for the graphically inclined user. Nothing bad to report.
It allows me to do coding without installing extra tools. I think its functionality is comparable to Atom. I only wish I could set dark theme without changing the theme for entire system.
summary: An excellent and very flexible editor if you install plugins

description: It works correctly, I am satisfied. Great app.
Nice if it has column mode.
summary: Nice if it has column mode

description: gedit is my first choice application for simple plain text editing when not using the command line. gedit fits very well in my Fedora desktop as it is one of the native GNOME applications. I think that all Linux users should try this app to decide themselves whether they find it useful.
One of the best text editors.
Considering many text editors and the main "already integrated" ones (aka notepad for windows, kate for kde and others, the Gedit is the best one, light, consistent, ease of use... I really like.
Despite having addons for font size selection still unable to select font size. No preference menu. Numerous other deficiencies and issues while using in RedHat.
summary: Trips out of the starting blocks

description: Quick, simple, and extensible this application is what it should be and can become more.
I'm typically an Atom user, but Gedit blows it away in terms of speed. Plus it's extensability allows for so many possibilities. I'll be watching closely, and who knows! Maybe I can contribute!

description:
Emoji is so important, that it has its own dedicated contextual menu item, right below "Select All"! 

On the other side there is no "Undo" / "Redo" - it is assumed that you will not need them (or that you remembered shortcuts from other applications).

Basic editing is easier, nicer and quicker done in Vim/Vi, advanced editing is entirely beyond the scope of this software.
summary: The most advanced feature here is "Insert Emoji"

description: yep. that's what i said. sad but true. i verified that there is a font size incompatibility with this app. i scaled my fonts, but the font size in the window is 5. yep, then when i go to uninstall "text editor", i find it is operating under the guise of "gedit", which, for some reason, there are two of in my installed apps, and can not be uninstalled. in addition to giving it a 1 star, i would like to state here and for the record "boooo"
Very nice and lightweight
It's not perfect but it has all basic features which I usually need. Syntax highlighting, tabs, refresh from disk... I'm satisfied.

It is a great tool for code editing when you don't want a whole IDE in your system.
It's Terminal integration feature is very useful.
Nice work team.

Light, functional, opens every kind of file, customizable.. perfect.
summary: I wish Windows had something well made like this text editor

description: its very important compiler for so many languages ..
"Good and simple text editor, nothing special"

Fast and simple to use. With some plugins, it can even be ok to learn coding. However if you do full time studies or work in programming, there are better editors.

Make sure to select RPM version, not Flatpak version, to be able to install plugins easily from here.
summary: Good for basic editing up to beginner coding

description: If you want an IDE, use VS Code or another electron based monster. This thing does its job, and does it well. It's simple, lightweight, fast, and has support for highlighting a ton of languages. There's also a ton of plugins you can add in if you want to extend it further. The UI is well thought out and easy to understand.
summary: It's a text editor, not an IDE

description:
Although I do not do much coding inside of this text editor, I have in the past however. It DOES work for that, and it actually does it very well. Aside from the plugins, and being able to easily) without having to learn a whole new thing, you can easily have a built in python console!
 The formatting and user interface of gedit is EXTREMELY clean, and well thought out. it integrates with the Gnome desktop and other Gnome software well also. I cant think of a time that I didn't use Gedit as my text editor. I have tried a few others, that I did like, but I always come back to the beautiful piece of software! Thank you Gnome Devs for this!

description: Great editor for writing basic programming codes like college assignments, competitive programming codes.

It's totally awesome. I used to use Geany but saw that this was smaller, so I checked out and was pleasantly surprised. It's syntax highlighting is so much better than Geany's, has a beautiful UI, and is very customizable via plugins.
Simple and practice. Thank you!
The highlighted line in dark theme is not visible

When I got this, I read one of the reviews, "The highlighted line in dark theme is not visible." This is completely true. The line highlight is the same color as the text on that line, so you can't see what you're typing. You can disable this highlighting and everything's perfect again (three-line-menu, preferences, uncheck highlight current line).
summary: Great text editor! (except dark them highlighting, see comment)
